text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits revised IRM 4.22.3, National Research Program (NRP), Classiﬁcation of NRP Returns.
The IRM was edited to accommodate the internal control information for the NRP. As part of this effort, the content was rearranged for readability and clarity
In addition, the IRM was reviewed to update references and other minor editorial changes.
This supersedes IRM 4.22.3 dated December 27, 2011.
Small Business/Self-Employed (SB/SE), Large Business & International (LB&I), and Tax Exempt and Government Entities (TE/GE) examination employees
Chief, National Research Program Knowledge, Development and Application Research, Applied Analytics and Statistics
Table of Contents
) Purpose. This IRM contains information related to the classiﬁcation of NRP case tax returns. The types of returns applicable to these cases include and nations of: • Form

) Audience. This information applies to IRS employees who participate in an NRP study including: • Classiﬁers • Examiners • Group managers • Reviewers • NRP staff (
) Director, Knowledge Development and Application, Research, Applied and Statistics (RAAS), is the policy owner. (
) NRP is the program office responsible for the oversight of the NRP studies. (
) For information about the National Research Program, visit the NRP at: http://nrp.web.irs.gov. (

) Each return in the NRP sample is randomly selected and weighted to represent hundreds or thousands of similar returns in the general ﬁling tion. Because of the statistical signiﬁcance of each return in the sample, all returns should be carefully scrutinized for indications of noncompliance. (

) In the NRP classiﬁcation process, every item on the return and on all ments will be considered, regardless of materiality or tax impact. There is limit to the number of issues that may be classiﬁed for NRP. (
) Director, Research Applied Analytics and Statistics (RAAS) (
) Director, Data Management Division (DMD) (
) Chief, National Research Program (NRP) (
) Compliance employees under: • Small Business and Self Employed (SB/SE) • Large Business and International (LB&I) • Tax Exempt/Government Entities (TE/GE) (

) Following is a list of the deﬁned terms applicable to classiﬁcation: a. Case building: The process of collecting information for classiﬁcation adding information to the case ﬁle, from both IRS and non-IRS Use of this information during the classiﬁcation process will help eliminate potential issues and provide the examiner with the maximum amount of information to guide the examination activity. For speciﬁc building items related to each study, see IRM
, NRP Case (
) Internal Revenue Manual
Purpose. This IRM contains information related to the classiﬁcation of NRP key case tax returns. The types of returns applicable to these cases include exami- nations of:

Case building: The process of collecting information for classiﬁcation and adding information to the case ﬁle, from both IRS and non-IRS sources. Use of this information during the classiﬁcation process will help identify or eliminate potential issues and provide the examiner with the maximum amount of information to guide the examination activity. For speciﬁc case building items related to each study, see IRM
, NRP Case Building.
National Research Program

b. Classiﬁcation: The process of identifying cases and issues for tion. c. Classiﬁed Issue List: A list of the issues identiﬁed during and included in each electronic case ﬁle. Each issue includes SAIN code, issue name, per return amount, form/schedule, line and any issue-related comments entered by the classiﬁer. Any related comments entered by the classiﬁer will also be bottom of the document. d. Information Reporting Program (IRP): Matching program income reported by third party entities to the amount reported taxpayer on the tax return. e. Key case returns: Returns identiﬁed by NRP through a process. Key case returns use AIMS Source Code

f. Report Generation Software: A comprehensive program used the examination process to perform a variety of audit and addition to computing tax, penalties, and interest on the report, RGS generates correspondence, work papers, and documents. (

) Following is a list of acronyms relating to classiﬁcation: a. AIMS - Audit Information Management System b. CDE - Certiﬁed Data Environment c. CRN - Credit Reference Number d. EIC - Earned Income Credit e. FAX - Facsimile f. IDRS - Integrated Data Retrieval System g. IMF- Individual Master File h. IRP - Information Reporting Program i. IRPTR - Information Returns Processing Transcript Requests j. LB&I - Large Business and International Division k. LUQ - Large, Unusual and Questionable l. NRP - National Research Program m. PSP - Planning and Special Programs n. RA - Revenue Agent o. RGS - Report Generation Software p. SB/SE - Small Business and Self Employed Division q. SSN - Social Security Number r. TCO - Tax Compliance Officer s. TE/GE - Tax Exempt and Government Entities Division (
) IRM
, National Research Program Overview (
) IRM
, Case Building (
) IRM
, IDRS Terminal Responses, for command code information (
) IRM
, Pre-Contact Analysis

b. Classiﬁcation: The process of identifying cases and issues for examina- tion. c. Classiﬁed Issue List: A list of the issues identiﬁed during classiﬁcation and included in each electronic case ﬁle. Each issue includes the IMF/ SAIN code, issue name, per return amount, form/schedule, line number, and any issue-related comments entered by the classiﬁer. Any case related comments entered by the classiﬁer will also be included at the bottom of the document. d. Information Reporting Program (IRP): Matching program that compares income reported by third party entities to the amount reported by the taxpayer on the tax return. e. Key case returns: Returns identiﬁed by NRP through a random selection process. Key case returns use AIMS Source Code

f. Report Generation Software: A comprehensive program used the examination process to perform a variety of audit and review tasks. In addition to computing tax, penalties, and interest on the examination report, RGS generates correspondence, work papers, and case closing documents.

In the NRP classiﬁcation process, every item on the return and on all attach- ments will be considered regardless of materiality or tax impact. There is no limit to the number of issues. Collectability Indicator will not be a consideration to accept a return as ﬁled.
of NRP Returns

) Classiﬁers will not classify returns they may examine. If they select a classify that they may be required to examine, they will immediately notify NRP Coordinator or the classiﬁcation coordinator so the case may be reas- signed. (

) Classiﬁers will ﬁrst review each return in its entirety for a general interrelationships among the income, expenses, credits and any other This review will include schedules, elections, and any other documents attached to the return. The classiﬁer can evaluate the signiﬁcance of items and use the appropriate case building material to identify items that potentially inaccurate and eliminate those with no potential for change. (

) Classiﬁers will compare the return to the transcripts in the case building mation. This will identify if the return has been amended or adjusted. The classiﬁer will make an entry in the “Case Related Comments” section of Classiﬁcation Return Form to alert the examiner to order any other returns or information. (
) Generally, all Large, Unusual and Questionable (LUQ) issues (deﬁned in

), will be classiﬁed for examination. In considering whether an is LUQ, the classiﬁer will judge whether there is a high probability, based their knowledge and experience, that the item is correct. If in doubt, the will be classiﬁed. (

) When warranted, the classiﬁer will identify related, prior and subsequent returns for examination. They will check all case related documents to determine whether the taxpayer has ﬁled all required returns. The will also include checks for ﬁling of information returns. The classiﬁer will an entry in the “Case Related Comments” section of the Classiﬁcation Form to alert the examiner to order any other required returns or (
) Many tax return amounts can be corroborated using case building material. the case building material matches the items reported on the tax return, generally the item will not be classiﬁed. (
) Classiﬁers may use any research tools, reference materials, or job aids available to them. (
) The information in this section applies to the classiﬁcation of NRP Form Individual tax returns. This information also covers Forms
A and of (

) NRP classiﬁcation guidelines training contains in-depth information and tions for classiﬁers on the classiﬁcation of the selected NRP returns. The training also provides instructions for accessing and using the NRP tion system. (

) All classiﬁed NRP returns are available for review by a trained reviewer. each classiﬁed return, the NRP reviewer must perform a full review, a review, or accept the classiﬁcation results without review. (

) The Area NRP Coordinators will serve as the classiﬁcation reviewers. all classiﬁed NRP returns will be fully reviewed. They will review the initial returns of each classiﬁer with the goal of consistent application of the cation guidelines and also for consistency between classiﬁers. Classiﬁers receive feedback from the classiﬁcation reviewer on their work.
The information in this section applies to the classiﬁcation of NRP Form 1040 Individual tax returns. This information also covers Forms 1040A and 1040EZ.
(12-29-2017) NRP Classiﬁcation of Form 1040 Returns
4.22 National Research Program (NRP)
) After the Coordinator/reviewer is satisﬁed as to the quality and consistency each classiﬁer’s returns, classiﬁcation review will be reduced to an overall
percent sample of returns classiﬁed during the classiﬁcation session. Quality and consistency of classiﬁcation will be stressed. (

) All classiﬁed NRP returns selected as “Accepted as Filed,” “Accepted with justments” and “Correspondence” will be reviewed. Also, the reviewers will verify any classiﬁed return where the classiﬁer has made a change to a “Per Database” item during classiﬁcation. (
) At the conclusion of the classiﬁcation detail, the reviewers will provide each classiﬁer with a written non-evaluative assessment of their work on the ment. (

) Coordinators who return to the ﬁeld will not examine any cases they or error checked during any classiﬁcation session. The coordinator’s review status can be veriﬁed by reviewing the Classiﬁed Issue List. (

) The classiﬁer must determine if the return is complete and contains all necessary forms and schedules. Any forms or schedules identiﬁed by the siﬁer as missing should be classiﬁed on the appropriate line item. If the line or Line Items item cannot be determined, the classiﬁer should use the “Case Related Comments” section of the Classiﬁcation Return Form to describe the missing item. (

) The classiﬁer should always look for and consider missing line items. They classify and document all potential missing line items on the appropriate line item of the Classiﬁcation Return Form and provide information in the “Comments” box of the classiﬁed issue. (
) The NRP Classiﬁcation Return system is accessed through a secure web (

Classiﬁcation Return forms that will
depending on the type of return ﬁled: Return • Form

EZ (
) The NRP Form
Classiﬁcation Return form is completed and reviewed electronically. Speciﬁc instructions for accessing and using the automated
Classiﬁcation System are provided to classiﬁers and reviewers during training. (
) The classiﬁcation data will be accumulated for analysis and used to populate the classiﬁed items in RGS prior to the returns being sent to the Area PSP Campus for audit. (
) The classiﬁer’s SEID number and date classiﬁed will be captured by the system. If the classiﬁed return is reviewed, the Classiﬁcation Reviewer’s and the date reviewed will also be captured. (

) The Classiﬁcation Return form will display the dollar amounts as shown on tax return. Every item with an amount other than zero must be considered a classiﬁcation determination of Veriﬁed, Classiﬁed or Not LUQ must be made. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

Classiﬁcation Return form is completed and reviewed electronically. Speciﬁc instructions for accessing and using the automated NRP
Classiﬁcation System are provided to classiﬁers and reviewers during training. (
) The classiﬁcation data will be accumulated for analysis and used to populate the classiﬁed items in RGS prior to the returns being sent to the Area PSP or Campus for audit. (
) The classiﬁer’s SEID number and date classiﬁed will be captured by the system. If the classiﬁed return is reviewed, the Classiﬁcation Reviewer’s SEID and the date reviewed will also be captured. (

) The Classiﬁcation Return form will display the dollar amounts as shown on the tax return. Every item with an amount other than zero must be considered and a classiﬁcation determination of Veriﬁed, Classiﬁed or Not LUQ must be made.
(12-29-2017) NRP Form 1040 Classiﬁcation Return System
NRP Returns
) After reviewing the classiﬁed issues on the return, the classiﬁer will select a classiﬁcation result of: a. Accepted as Filed, b. Accepted with Adjustments, c. Correspondence, d. TCO, or e. RA (
) When necessary, classiﬁers include speciﬁc comments regarding why the issue was classiﬁed. (

) There are several issues on the Classiﬁcation Return form that require the classiﬁer to select whether the item pertains to the primary or secondary Security Number (or both). a. “P” refers to the ﬁrst (primary) Social Security Number listed on the and b. “S” refers to the second Social Security Number on the return. (

) Following are some speciﬁc guidelines to help identify the mandatory and prevalent issues to be classiﬁed. Detailed line item classiﬁcation instructions are provided to the selected NRP classiﬁers during classiﬁcation training. (
) The examination and documentation of the Earned Income Credit is an part of an NRP Form
study. (
) If the Earned Income Credit is claimed on the return it will always be (

) To classify EIC, select one or more of the following issues: • Exemptions: Dependent Children Who Lived with Taxpayer • Exemptions: Dependent Children Who Did Not Live With Taxpayer • Exemptions: Other • EIC for Qualifying Children (Not Listed as Dependents) • EIC With No Children (

) When EIC is classiﬁed and the above issues are selected, the classiﬁer will also select any or all the issues that may be related to EIC including: • Dependents • Filing Status • Child and Dependent Care Credit • Credit for the Elderly or the Disabled • Education Credits • Child Tax Credit • Adoption Credit (
) Taxpayers claiming EIC with qualifying children must be examined by a RA TCO. (
) Taxpayers claiming EIC with no children may be examined by the Campus Correspondence Unit.
(12-29-2017) Speciﬁc Guidelines for Classifying Forms and Schedules
The examination and documentation of the Earned Income Credit is an part of an NRP Form

study. If the Earned Income Credit is claimed on the return it will always be To classify EIC, select one or more of the following issues: • Exemptions: Dependent Children Who Lived with Taxpayer • Exemptions: Dependent Children Who Did Not Live With Taxpayer • Exemptions: Other • EIC for Qualifying Children (Not Listed as Dependents) • EIC With No Children When EIC is classiﬁed and the above issues are selected, the classiﬁer also select any or all the issues that may be related to EIC including: • Dependents • Filing Status • Child and Dependent Care Credit • Credit for the Elderly or the Disabled • Education Credits • Child Tax Credit • Adoption Credit Taxpayers claiming EIC with qualifying children must be examined by a TCO. Taxpayers claiming EIC with no children may be examined by the Correspondence Unit.
Taxpayers claiming EIC with no children may be examined by the Campus Correspondence Unit.
National Research Program (
) In general, every income item on the return that cannot be substantiated by case building materials is classiﬁed. (

) Generally, the IDRS IRPTR data is the best source of case building for verifying an income amount on a given tax return line item. IRP data can be used to verify wages, interest, dividends, and miscellaneous income. The IRP data will also verify ﬂow-through amounts from Forms
S and
) Schedule C income items will always be classiﬁed even when veriﬁed by (

) Some Schedule F income items will be classiﬁed regardless of their even if they match IRP documents. The remaining Schedule F income items will be classiﬁed unless veriﬁed by case building material. For additional guidance, see IRM

) Schedule B, Schedule D and Schedule E income items will be classiﬁed unless they can be veriﬁed by case building. Additionally, these income should be classiﬁed if there is a potential for unreported income even when amounts are veriﬁed by case building. (
) In using the IRP documents to verify amounts reported on the tax return, classiﬁer may disregard a speciﬁc mismatch if it is below the tolerance set NRP or appears to be a rounding discrepancy. (
) Income items will also be classiﬁed if the taxpayer’s occupation provides a likely opportunity for moonlighting, receipt of tips, bartering, constructive dividends, etc. (

) The classiﬁer will consider indications on the return that the taxpayer(s) had insufficient income to support their standard of living. For example: a. If gross itemized deductions exceed Adjusted Gross Income, classify “income.” b. If the classiﬁer questions whether the taxpayer(s) has enough income sustain their apparent lifestyle, classify the “Other Income” issue and provide notes in the “Comments” box. c. The classiﬁer may recommend “Indirect Method” if they believe a more thorough examination of income is warranted. (

) All LUQ items on the return will be classiﬁed for examination. The LUQ are applied to any line items that are not required to be classiﬁed. LUQs are items that appear on the return which, if left unexplained, might raise doubt cause confusion to a reviewer of the completed examination. (

) The deﬁnition of an LUQ item will depend on the classiﬁer’s perception of return as a whole and the separate items that comprise the return. Some factors to consider when identifying LUQs are: a. The comparative size of the item, b. The absolute size of the item, c. The inherent character of the item, d. Evidence of intent to mislead, etc.
4.22 National Research Program
In general, every income item on the return that cannot be substantiated by case building materials is classiﬁed.
The classiﬁer will consider indications on the return that the taxpayer(s) had insufficient income to support their standard of living. For example:

a. If gross itemized deductions exceed Adjusted Gross Income, classify “income.” b. If the classiﬁer questions whether the taxpayer(s) has enough income to sustain their apparent lifestyle, classify the “Other Income” issue and provide notes in the “Comments” box. c. The classiﬁer may recommend “Indirect Method” if they believe a more thorough examination of income is warranted.
(12-29-2017) Large, Unusual or Questionable (LUQ) Criteria
of NRP Returns
) The Head of Household ﬁling status will always be classiﬁed on all NRP returns. – Head of (
) If the NRP return claims a Net Operating Deduction under Other Income, it always be classiﬁed. Loss (
) This issue is always classiﬁed if an IRPTR discrepancy exists. (
) If the issue is classiﬁed and meets the established referral criteria as Credit IRM
, the classiﬁer must state in the “Comments” box that there is a Mandatory International Referral. (

) Schedule A (Itemized Deductions) items above a pre-determined NRP threshold will be classiﬁed. This is the most signiﬁcant exception to Itemized LUQ criteria for NRP. Small adjustments to itemized deduction amounts extremely signiﬁcant for NRP research purposes because of the great of taxpayers that itemize their deductions. (
) Items on Schedule A that can be corroborated by case building information not need to be classiﬁed. For example, Home Mortgage Interest and deducted on Schedule A can be veriﬁed from Form

information on IRPTR document. Because some taxpayers may be limited in the amount their allowable deduction, classiﬁers must classify this issue if it is a high amount rather than accept the amount claimed because it matches the
amount. (

) The classiﬁer will not consider total itemized deduction phase-out rules on income. For Schedule A deductions limited by AGI (Medical and Dental Expenses, Job Expenses and Certain Miscellaneous Deductions), the will be classiﬁed after the AGI limitation is taken into account. (
) Employee business expenses from Form
or Form
-EZ are using a pre-determined NRP threshold. The classiﬁer will designate the schedule pertains to the primary or secondary Social Security Number both. (
) Income items on Schedule C , Proﬁt or Loss From Business and Schedule C-EZ, Net Proﬁt From Business, will be classiﬁed even if the amounts IRP documents. Income (
) Expenses on these schedules (including Cost of Goods Sold) will generally classiﬁed using the LUQ criteria. (
) The classiﬁer will designate whether the schedule pertains to the primary secondary Social Security Number or both. (
) If the classiﬁer believes the Schedule C they are classifying may not be engaged in for a proﬁt, they will classify the issue under “Section
– Proﬁt Activity.” (

) The classiﬁer will also classify “Interest – Mortgage” and “Taxes and These expenses are classiﬁed as they may be claimed on the Schedule C may be allowable on Schedule A. (
) In general, all line items on Schedule D are classiﬁed using the LUQ including any IRP discrepancies. D – Capital (
) All identiﬁed Like-Kind Exchanges will be classiﬁed whether or not the return and Losses was ﬁled with Form
, Like-Kind Exchanges. (

) On Schedule E Part I (Supplemental Income and Loss - Rental Real Estate and Royalties), income items will be classiﬁed unless they can be E – Income or by case building information. Expenses will generally be classiﬁed using the from Rental Real LUQ criteria except for “Mortgage Interest ”which must be veriﬁed using Royalties, building information. S (

) On Schedule E Part II (Income or Loss from Partnerships and S etc. the classiﬁer will classify any Partnership or S Corporation return that does reconcile to the IRP document provided in the case building materials. ers will identify any other ﬂow-through entity for examination using the LUQ criteria. They will consider whether the taxpayer exercises control or inﬂuence over the entity, the taxpayer’s percentage ownership of the entity, whether the ﬂow-through entity return is a ﬁrst or ﬁnal year return, etc. (
) Schedule E Parts III (Income or Loss from Estates and Trusts) and IV or Loss From Real Estate Mortgage Investment Conduits) will be classiﬁed similarly to Part II using LUQ criteria. (

) The following Schedule F income items will be classiﬁed regardless of their amount, even if they match IRP documents: F – Income or • Sch F Sales of Livestock & Other Resale Items (Cash) from Farming • Sch F Sales of Livestock, Produce, Grains and Other Products You Raised (Cash) • Sch F Custom Hire (Machine Work) Income (Cash) • Sch F Other income (Cash) • Sch F Sales of Livestock, produce, grains, and other products • Sch F Custom Hire (Machine Work) Income (Accrual) • Sch F Other Income (Accrual) (

) The remaining Schedule F income items will be classiﬁed unless veriﬁed by case building material. Schedule F expenses are classiﬁed using the LUQ criteria except for “Mortgage Interest” which must be veriﬁed using case building information. The classiﬁer will designate whether the schedule to the primary or secondary Social Security Number or both. (
) If the classiﬁer believes the Schedule F they are classifying may not be engaged in for proﬁt, they will classify the issue under “Section

– Not Proﬁt Activity.” The classiﬁer will also classify “Interest-Mortgage,” “Interest- Other” and “Taxes.” These expenses are classiﬁed as they may be claimed the Schedule F but may be allowable on Schedule A.
National Research Program

The following Schedule F income items will be classiﬁed regardless of their amount, even if they match IRP documents: • Sch F Sales of Livestock & Other Resale Items (Cash) • Sch F Sales of Livestock, Produce, Grains and Other Products You Raised (Cash) • Sch F Custom Hire (Machine Work) Income (Cash) • Sch F Other income (Cash) • Sch F Sales of Livestock, produce, grains, and other products (Accrual) • Sch F Custom Hire (Machine Work) Income (Accrual) • Sch F Other Income (Accrual) The remaining Schedule F income items will be classiﬁed unless veriﬁed by case building material. Schedule F expenses are classiﬁed using the LUQ criteria except for “Mortgage Interest” which must be veriﬁed using case building information. The classiﬁer will designate whether the schedule pertains to the primary or secondary Social Security Number or both. If the classiﬁer believes the Schedule F they are classifying may not be engaged in for proﬁt, they will classify the issue under “Section

– Not for Proﬁt Activity.” The classiﬁer will also classify “Interest-Mortgage,” “Interest- Other” and “Taxes.” These expenses are classiﬁed as they may be claimed on the Schedule F but may be allowable on Schedule A.
The following Schedule F income items will be classiﬁed regardless of their amount, even if they match IRP documents:
of NRP Returns
) The NRP tax return will be completely classiﬁed prior to the determination the classiﬁcation results. (
) After classifying the return, the classiﬁer will indicate the overall result on Classiﬁcation Return Form based on criteria deﬁned in the following (
) All returns designated as “Accepted as Filed,”, “Accepted with Adjustments” “Correspondence” will be reviewed and concurred by the NRP Coordinator classiﬁcation reviewer. (

) The classiﬁed NRP return will be designated as “Accepted as Filed” if all following criteria apply: a. The total of all classiﬁed issues is less than the total return tolerance, b. There are no income items which cannot be veriﬁed by case building, c. There are no non-dollar items for related party transactions, and d. There are no discrepancies related to IRP documents or processing errors. (
) If there are issues for which dollar amounts are not known, (such as, Other income - standard of living, Schedule C/F - Gross Receipts, etc.), will select the return for audit. (

) If there is a potential issue involving a related party transaction, a sale of property, or indication that an indirect method is required to identify income, classiﬁers will select the return for audit. (
) A return will be “Accepted with Adjustments” if it would have been as Filed” except there are discrepancies related to IRP documents or ing errors. (
) The classiﬁer will enter the IRP discrepancy or processing error (for a transcription error) on the NRP

Classiﬁcation Return Form by the appropriate issue, verifying the “Per Database” amount, and writing an planation in the “Comments” box referring to the applicable case building document and noting the amount of the discrepancy. (
) Correspondence examiners will audit returns containing no more than ﬁve the issues shown in Exhibit

, Correspondence Examination More than one issue in a category of similar classiﬁed issues are only as one issue for the total Correspondence issue count. Example: The classiﬁer may select “Schedule A State and Local Income “Schedule A Real Estate Taxes” and “Schedule A Personal Property Taxes.” These three issues relate to the Schedule A Taxes and they counted as only one issue towards the total Correspondence issue count.
After classifying the return, the classiﬁer will indicate the overall result on the Classiﬁcation Return Form based on criteria deﬁned in the following sections.

The classiﬁer may select “Schedule A State and Local Income Taxes,” “Schedule A Real Estate Taxes” and “Schedule A Personal Property Taxes.” These three issues relate to the Schedule A Taxes and they are counted as only one issue towards the total Correspondence issue count.
National Research Program (

) Earned Income Credit returns with No Children can be selected for dence exam. EIC with children, any other EIC related issues, or returns ﬁnancial status concerns will not be selected for a Correspondence tion. (

) Classiﬁers will select returns for Area Examination (TCO or RA) if the issues exceed the total return tolerances or there are non-dollar items for Examination related party transactions or indications of potential unreported income. (
) Returns are selected for Area Examination if they do not meet the issue lines for Correspondence returns. (

) The classiﬁer will determine whether the classiﬁed return should be to a TCO or RA based on Area guidance from the NRP Coordinator. This ignation by the classiﬁer will determine the type of mandatory issues and workpapers that will be provided in the NRP RGS case ﬁle. (

) The initial determination of the type of case may be changed by the Area depending on the issues selected on the return or the availability of in locations that may be trained and available to examine NRP returns. (
) Generally, the classiﬁer will identify a return for assignment to a TCO if it not have a Schedule C, Schedule F or Schedule E Page
(ﬂow-through Compliance Officer returns). (
) These returns will generally be Activity Codes
through
although may be some Schedule C or F returns included in codes
and
be identiﬁed for an RA. (
) Generally, the classiﬁer will identify a return for assignment to a RA if it contains a Schedule C, Schedule F, or Schedule E Page
(ﬂow-through Agent (RA) returns). These returns will generally be Activity Codes
through
) The return may also be designated for an RA if the overall issues are mined too complex for a TCO, or if an Indirect Method is indicated. (

) All LUQ issues will be classiﬁed for examination. In considering whether issue is LUQ, the classiﬁer will judge whether there is a high probability, on the classiﬁer’s knowledge and experience, that the item is correct. If in doubt, the classiﬁer will classify the item. (

) Classiﬁers will classify every line item in the Income section of the Form
where a dollar ﬁgure is shown on the Form
S. If the classiﬁer Section questions an item in the Income section where there is no dollar entry on return, they will provide an explanation in the “Comments” column. (

) Classiﬁers will also select other income items that are present on the K if there are dollar amounts on these line items. Interest, Ordinary and Qualiﬁed Dividends will be classiﬁed if there is nothing in the ﬁle to their correctness (IRP transcript). (
) If Other Income (Loss) is selected, the classiﬁer will review the individual items on any schedule attached to the return to determine if one or more the items meets the LUQ criteria. (

are referenced to Form

In the NRP classiﬁcation process, every item on the return and all attachments are considered, regardless of materiality or tax impact.
The following issues are always classiﬁed for Form 1120 cases.

National Research Program • Like-Kind Exchanges • Loans To Shareholders • Loans From Shareholders • Net Operating Losses (NOLs) • Officer-Shareholder Compensation • Related Party Transactions • Schedule M (
) Additional issues in the NRP
automated classiﬁcation process are selected based on their relationship to other items on the return and LUQ criteria. (
) Some of the beneﬁts of using an automated classiﬁcation process include: a. Applying classiﬁcation guidelines in an objective manner across all in the

study b. Allowing data to be validated before cases are released to the ﬁeld front end data validation rather than waiting for cases to be closed c. Saving resources by not requiring RAs to be detailed for classiﬁcation signments d. Allowing for ﬂexible classiﬁcation criteria, and e. Using a process where all returns included in a study year can be ﬁed in minutes after complete data has been assembled. (
) Due to the nature of Employment Taxes, issues for examination must be tablished at the Examiner level. An “issue list” will be provided as part of of Data Capture Instrument (DCI-
) and any issues that affect the entity will Tax deﬁne the minimum scope of the examination. (
) All issues must be included in the DCI-
- Workpapers ﬁle. (
) Examiners should be aware of other issues that impact the NRP Tax year. Examiners must expand the scope of the NRP year examination other issues, regardless of materiality. (
) The following issues are classiﬁed on the DCI-
and must be addressed every NRP employment tax key case: • Form
